p: 80% of the human population depends on plants for their primary health care [ 6]. As many as 35000 plant species have been screened for anti-cancer activities previously, leading to the discovery of clinically important anti-cancer drugs such as Vincristine, Vinblastine, Taxol, Indicineâ€“ N-oxide, Etoposides and Camptothecin, with ability to inhibit growth of cancer cells by controlling apoptosis and autophagic pathways [ 7]. However, due to multidrug resistance and toxic effects of current chemotherapeutic drugs to other non-target tissues, development of new bioactive molecules with fewer side effects and greater efficacy is essential [ 8].
